awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Modeling Student Knowledge and Improving Performance when Learning from Multiple Types of Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
As the national interest in higher and professional education has been increasing, interest in online learning systems has also grown rapidly. Online learning systems, such as Massive Open Online Courses and Intelligent Tutoring Systems, aim to contribute to the society by providing high quality, affordable, and accessible education, at scale. They highly impact advancement of the national prosperity by preparing skillful professionals for high-demand jobs. Delivering such high-impact goals requires automatic tools that can help us understand students' learning process and answer questions such as what knowledge is gained by watching a video lecture (domain knowledge modeling), what is a student's state of knowledge (student knowledge modeling), and how a specific student would perform on a test (predicting student performance). Ideally, these tools should model student's learning from various learning material types (such as problems, readings, and video lectures) and capture the knowledge span offered by combinations of gradable and non-gradable learning resources. However, the current tools are limited to a single type of learning material (typically, "problems"), ignoring the heterogeneity of learning materials from which students may learn. This project aims to achieve a better understanding of students' learning process in online educational systems by presenting an integrated research and education plan (1) to model student interactions with both gradable and non-gradable learning material types, (2) to integrate the proposed models with learning material content, and (3) to evaluate the proposed models by experimenting with real-world online educational datasets. The project will provide learning and research opportunities to graduate and undergraduate students.

To achieve the goal of improving students' learning process in online educational systems, the researchers develop multi-view machine learning algorithms that minimize the error of student performance prediction while maximizing the correlations among multiple views of the learning data. In the first year of this project, using activity sequences of students a model will be built that can capture a shared latent knowledge space among sets of gradable learning material and non-gradable ones. During the second year of this project, content information of learning materials, including expert labels, will be included in the learning model in order to improve it. This model aims to discover the relationship between content information and the shared latent knowledge space. The project results are evaluated using the task of predicting student performance. This project is at the intersection of domain adaptation, sequence modeling, and educational data mining. The model is inspired by Canonical Correlation Analysis as an approach for transferring information and adapting various views to student activity data, while modeling student learning process as a sequence of knowledge acquisitions. This is a novel treatment of the student modeling problem, with a sequential domain-adaptation view, that facilitates future research directions, such as personalized education and improved student retention in online learning environments. This work contributes novel sequential and content-aware domain adaptation and multi-variate analysis models that combine information from multiple sequential data sources and time-invariant content resources at the same time. While motivated by the task of student knowledge modeling, the models are general and can be applied to a broad spectrum of research including domain adaptation problems and recommender systems. The developed solutions will be presented in journals and conference venues, and the project website will provide access to the results, with references to code for the developed and evaluated models that will be available at GitHub.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Interest in online learning systems has grown rapidly in recent years. The online learning systems aim to address the demand for high quality, affordable, and goal-oriented education at scale. At this scale, understanding students' learning processes is essential for the success of such systems. In these systems, students learn from a diverse set of learning materials, such as the "assessed" problems or quizzes and the "non-assessed" reading materials or video lectures. In this context, Educational Data Mining approaches aim to answer questions such as what knowledge is offered in a video lecture or required to solve a problem (domain knowledge modeling) and what is a student's state of knowledge at each point of the learning period (student knowledge modeling). In this project, we noted that the student and domain knowledge modeling literature has mainly focused on the assessed learning materials, ignoring the non-assessed ones. Ignoring these types of learning materials will limit our understanding of how students learn, as the students benefit from activities such as reading the textbook and watching the video lectures, in addition to practicing the problems and quizzes. However, quantifying the combined effect of assessed and non-assessed learning materials on student knowledge is challenging, because student knowledge is not explicitly examined after interacting with the non-assessed learning materials, and is expected to grow in association with the interacted learning materials over time.

To address these challenges and model learning from various learning material types, we focused on 1) personalized modeling of student behavior in interacting with assessed vs. non-assessed learning materials, 2) modeling personalized knowledge gain and latent learning concepts from student historical interaction records with different kinds of learning materials, 2) representing gradual knowledge gain via various models, and 3) representing knowledge gain with the help of learning material content. For each of the above, throughout this project, we devised novel machine learning models and algorithms and experimented with them using simulated and real-world datasets. We developed a range of approaches for detecting the helpful vs. non-helpful student behaviors when interacting with assessed and non-assessed learning materials. Particularly, our developed models could separate the performance-related learning behaviors from the habit-related ones. Our experiments showed that spending enough time is necessary to benefit from both assessed and non-assessed learning materials; however, studying the non-assessed learning materials is most helpful for weaker students with lower prior knowledge.

To automatically quantify student knowledge-gain from their interaction with the learning materials and to extract learning materials' domain knowledge, we developed multiple novel personalized knowledge models from different model families (deep learning and tensor factorization models). Our experiments showed that our models can successfully integrate and quantify learning from assessed and non-assessed learning materials, significantly outperform the state-of-the-art knowledge models in terms of predicting student performance, can relate and identify the latent concepts of both assessed and non-assessed learning materials, and showed remarkable improvement in identifying the domain knowledge compared to the ones created by domain experts. We devised and experimented with various models of gradual knowledge gain for students, for which we covered a range of assumptions, from the most relaxed ones that did not constrain the knowledge gain in any way, to the strictest ones that assumed that the student knowledge monotonically increases as they interact with learning materials. We showed that the models with an overall knowledge gain trend while allowing for occasional forgetting of the learned materials while automatically summarizing the consequent attempts, best match the real-world datasets. We also created models that not only relied on student interactions, but also used learning material content to better represent student knowledge. We learned that this content integration increases the interpretability of both the student knowledge models and the learning material domain models.

We publicized our developed approaches and the codes associated with them for use by the public and other researchers. Our developed models can be adapted to be used in other domains, such as personalized health and recommender systems. After the completion of this project, we plan to continue and expand upon this work in these domains and use it in developing personalized educational recommender systems.
